title: Lists (Dynamic Collections)
simplifierConcept:
Arrays have a problem: FIXED SIZE!

‚ùå Array limitations:
int[] scores = new int[5];  // Stuck with 5!
// Want to add 6th item? Can't!

‚úÖ List solution:
List<int> scores = new List<int>();
scores.Add(10);  // Add first
scores.Add(20);  // Add second
scores.Add(30);  // Keep adding!
scores.Remove(20);  // Remove items!

List = Array that can GROW and SHRINK!

Key features:
üì¶ Dynamic size (grows automatically)
‚ûï Add items anytime (.Add)
‚ûñ Remove items anytime (.Remove)
üî¢ Still indexed (list[0], list[1]...)
üìä Same type (List<int>, List<string>)

Think: List = Flexible array that expands as needed!

syntaxBreakdown.explanation: List of specific type. List<int> holds integers. List<string> holds strings. <type> is required! Generic syntax - specifies what list contains.
Adds item to END of list. list.Add(5) appends 5. List automatically grows. Can add unlimited items (memory permitting).
Removes FIRST occurrence of item. list.Remove(5) removes first 5 found. Returns true if found/removed, false if not found.
Lists use .Count (property). Arrays use .Length (property). Both are properties (no parentheses!). list.Count, array.Length.

challenge.instructions:
Create a contact manager app!

1. Create empty List<string> for names and List<string> for phones
2. Show menu loop:
   - Add contact (name + phone)
   - Remove contact by name
   - Search contact by name
   - List all contacts
   - Exit
3. For Add: Get name and phone, add to both lists at same index
4. For Remove: Find index of name, remove from both lists
5. For Search: Find name, display name and phone
6. For List: Display all contacts with index numbers

Example:
=== CONTACT MANAGER ===
1. Add contact
2. Remove contact
3. Search contact
4. List all
5. Exit

Choice: 1
Name: Alice
Phone: 555-1234
Added!

Choice: 4
Contacts:
1. Alice - 555-1234

Choice: 3
Search name: Alice
Found: Alice - 555-1234
challenge.hint: Use List<string> for dynamic size. .Add(item) to append. .IndexOf(item) to find position (returns -1 if not found). .RemoveAt(index) to remove by position. Keep two lists synchronized with same index.
commonStickingPoints: Forgetting using: List needs using System.Collections.Generic; at top! Without it, List not recognized. Must include this namespace.
Count vs Length: Arrays use .Length. Lists use .Count. list.Length is ERROR! Remember: List = Count, Array = Length. Both are properties (no parentheses).
Remove vs RemoveAt: .Remove(item) removes by VALUE. .RemoveAt(index) removes by POSITION. list.Remove(5) removes value 5. list.RemoveAt(5) removes 6th item!
IndexOf returns -1: list.IndexOf(\"Bob\") returns -1 if not found! Must check: int i = list.IndexOf(x); if (i >= 0) { ... } before using index.
